awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Internet Protocol (IP)-enabled wireless interface for smart lights
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a way to connect different webcam lighting studio networks together, and to test the network stability in diverse, real-life scenarios. Although the innovation was initially inspired by needs in the theatre industry, the technology may be applied to any webcam environment that could benefit from lighting design control, whether local or remote. Virtual theatre allows a company to expand its audiences beyond a geographic region and provides the ability to produce high-quality dramatic experiences at a fraction of the cost. The theatre industry may have the ability to reach a wider demographic, including the economically disadvantaged, the elderly, and people with disabilities.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an Internet Protocol (IP)-enabled wireless interface for a set of smart lights that can be controlled by a central operator over the Internet. The technology is developed to provide customized options for live virtual theater, teleconferencing, online education, and other applications. The interfaces differs in pre-set lighting options as well as in the activities available to the operator. The prototype was developed for both video recording by a single-user video recording and for multi-user theaters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 global pandemic ushered in a period of explosive growth of web and video conferencing services. Even after the pandemic ended, businesses, educational institutions, conferences and other meeting organizers have continued to practice virtual meetings due to convenience, affordability, and the ability to reach new audiences. Consequently, the need for novel and flexible solutions for controlling lighting for online video meetings and presentations has continued to be an important issue. In addition to achieving professional appearances to match location-specific ambient lighting and backgrounds of online video users, the need for lighting control for virtual presentations is critical for special applications such as digital theater where an online equivalent of a lighting designer is required. This project addresses the need for extending the use of DMX512 protocol, which is the widely used industry protocol to control the lights for commercial light shows and stage lighting shows, for virtual appearances. In a virtual performance, the performers are usually located at different locations, each having their own lighting system set up to provide adequate illumination for the webcam operation. However, current webcam lighting systems lack the ability to provide special effects and variations of lighting that would be required at various instances during live performances that are normally controlled by a lighting operator. 

In this project, we developed a centralized interface where a single operator can have access to the webcam lighting of multiple users present at different locations and control the lights at various instances during the performance. The operator can control the color and intensity of multiple lights for multiple users located at different locations participating in a virtual presentation. The operator is able to do so in a convenient manner and in real-time. This system makes use of one or more small single-board computers (SBCs) and a wireless DMX transmitter as the wireless interface that can be used to control the DMX webcam lights. The proposed system makes use of a cloud-based web-server, database, and communication over the internet. A web interface is designed to issue commands to the SBCs to control DMX lights associated with the presenter. Multiple wireless interfaces, each for a specific user at a different location, can be simultaneously configured and managed using the web interface. The proposed system enables an operator to provide optimum and artistic lighting effects for a group of online presenters. Future implementations of the proposed system can be configured with AI based automatic lighting parameter selection based on background matching, scene preferences, and other theatrical effects.

The project also explored commercialization opportunities of the proposed network-operated lighting system for virtual presentations that could be adapted to a variety of different environments, including professional studio, online learning, and theatrical presentations. Potential adaptations included: (a) configurations of light universes needed, (b) pre-set lighting, (c) lighting sequences, (d) operator interface requirements. Customer inputs were also conducted to determine the interest in flexibility versus ease of set-up, local versus remote control, and the need for customized solutions. Market survey indicates that cost and ease of use are the key factors that would determine the success of the proposed product for commercialization.
